question: A 14-year-old adolescent suddenly begins choking while having dinner and is in severe distress. What life-saving intervention must be done immediately?

A child requires multiple minor surgical procedures in the nasopharynx. Which drug has high surface local anesthetic activity and intrinsic vasoconstrictor actions that reduce bleeding in the mucous membrane?

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting and headache for the past hour. He had a road traffic accident this morning. Glasgow's consciousness score is E4M6V4. Pupils are anisocoric and reactive. CT scan reveals a biconvex hyperdensity over the right temporoparietal region along with a fracture of the temporal bone. What is the most likely source of the blood?

A 40-year-old married man presents to the emergency room with coarse tremors and visual hallucinations. He is unable to identify his family members. When asked about the time of the day he gives an incorrect answer. He also gives vague answers on the hospital whereabouts. Detailed history reveals regular and heavy alcohol intake for the last 10 years. On examination his pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg and respiratory rate of 32 per min. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 19-year-old male is brought by his father to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of singing out loud throughout the night, sleeplessness, and claiming he is a famous singer. He had one similar episode in the past and one previous episode with symptoms of low energy and mood, for which he received treatment and reached a pre-morbid level of functionality. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following anesthetics allows patients to ambulate faster and has the lowest risk of postoperative vomiting?
Which of these reduces intracranial pressure?

answers.option: Keep patient lying in prone position

question: A 2-year-old baby is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of progressive lower limb weakness for the last five days. He has a history of viral sore throat ten days back. On examination, reflexes are absent in both lower limbs. The child is otherwise conscious and vitally stable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which drug has the capacity to reverse the effects of opioids?
Which of the following anti-depressants has a stronger risk of self-harm and suicide?
Why is procaine relatively contraindicated in patients with cardiovascular or pulmonary diseases?

answers.option: It causes decompensation through formation of methemoglobin
It acts as a chelating agent
It acts as a beta-agonist in the heart and lungs
It inhibits cyclooxygenase in cardiac and pulmonary cells

question: The potency of inhaled anesthetics is defined as the minimum alveolar concentration. Which of the following denotes the minimum alveolar concentration of nitrous oxide?

A 54-year-old male was admitted to the hospital for a laparoscopic hernia repair under general anesthesia. A suitable dose of diazepam was given intravenously, and the patient quickly lost consciousness. He regained consciousness 45 minutes later even though the half-life of diazepam is 40 hours. What is the most appropriate reason for the short duration of action of the drug in this case?

answers.option: Biotransformation of the drug to active metabolites by the liver
Rapid metabolism of the drug within the central nervous system
Development of rapid tolerance to the drug effects
Rapid excretion of the drug by the kidneys
Redistribution of the drug from the central nervous system to other tissues

question: A 35-year-old male complains to his physician about attacks of intense terror during sleep, such as feeling crushed, and often waking up with a scream, but is unable to remember any specific dream. He also feels anxious and restless from time to time during the day. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for acutely improving the patient's symptoms?
Which of the following anti-parkinsonian drugs may cause vasospasm?

A recently widowed 76-year-old woman is prescribed benzodiazepines for several weeks after the death of her husband, but she does not like the daytime sedation it causes even at low doses. Since her depressive symptoms are not improving, the physician decides to prescribe an antidepressant medication. Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate in this case?

A 35-year-old male is prescribed citalopram for depression. He stops taking the drug due to a negative impact on his sexual performance. Which of the following antidepressants should be started in this patient in place of citalopram?

An 8-year-old male is brought to the clinic with complaints of multiple fits periodically for the past year. These episodes are generalized tonic-clonic convulsions followed by tongue biting and loss of consciousness. His uncle had similar complaints in his childhood which were cured by medication. What is the investigation of choice to make a definitive diagnosis?

A 3-year-old unvaccinated male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high fever and sudden loss of ability to walk and stand. He also complains of severe body aches and backaches, but bladder and bowel control are intact. On examination, he is conscious and responsive with asymmetry of limb movements. There is hypotonia and hyporeflexia with power 2/5 in the left lower limb. The remaining motor examination is unremarkable. The sensation is normal in all limbs. What is the best diagnostic test in this case?

A 60-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremors. The patient was diagnosed as a case of Parkinson's disease. Which of the following drugs is an appropriate combination for this patient?

A 25-year-old female with generalized seizures is well-controlled on valproate. She indicates that she is interested in becoming pregnant next year. With respect to her antiseizure medication, which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in her therapy?

answers.option: Leave her on her current theraoy
Consider adding a second antiseizure medication
Stop the therapy during her pregnancy

question: An adult male is recently diagnosed as a case of schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drugs is most likely to improve his apathy and blunted affect?
Which of the following antipsychotics is considered to be the most potent and thus carries the greatest risk for causing extrapyramidal symptoms?

A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a complaint of weakness in the right side of the body. The child has no history of fever. On examination, his vitals are normal and cyanosis is present. On auscultation, a murmur is found to be present. What is the most likely cause of this condition?

A 6-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, vomiting, altered sensorium, and weakness of the left side of the body. An urgent computed tomography (CT) brain was planned. What is the purpose of an urgent CT brain in such cases?

A 30-year-old male patient with a spinal cord injury is admitted for comprehensive rehabilitation. His neurological examination reveals intact sensory function, but no motor function is preserved below the neurological level at S4 and S5. What will be the grading of this patient according to the American Spinal Injury Association Impairment (ASIA) scale?

A 35-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of pain, inability to close his right eye, and bilateral loss of vision for one week. He also reports fever, and flu-like symptoms as well as a distinctive rash resembling a bull's eye on his arm a few weeks prior to the onset of these symptoms. On examination, he had bilateral papillitis and right-sided lower motor neuron facial palsy. MRI brain is suggestive of white matter lesions. Cerebrospinal fluid has predominant lymphocytes, normal sugars, and raised proteins. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 65-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic after falling several times in the past few months. On examination, the most notable findings are a wide unstable gait and marked retropulsion. He also has bradykinesia, mask facies, and dysarthria. There is no evidence of cogwheeling or resting tremor. His symptoms do not respond to levodopa/carbidopa. His eye movements are notable for their vertical saccades, and fast phases. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male shopkeeper is brought to the emergency room by his son due to his inability to recall names and phone numbers with some odd behavior since one day. He had recently been prescribed sleeping pills by a nearby doctor a few days prior to the illness. There is no history of fever, fits, trauma, or loss of consciousness. On examination, he is awake, inattentive, confused, and disoriented to place. There are no signs of meningeal irritation. The rest of the examination was unremarkable. What is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case?

A 30-year-old male sustained a severe head injury in a road traffic accident 3 months back, following which he becomes unconscious, and required ventilatory support. He is currently still on ventilatory support, although he does make his own breaths as well. On examination, he has intact corneal, doll's eyes, and pupillary responses. There is no verbal response, although there is occasional eye-opening, and yawning. He is able to move all his limbs against gravity, but only on deep pain. His blood pressure, temperature, and pulse are within normal range. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 40-year-old boxer sustains a head injury during a tournament and is immediately rushed to the hospital. He is opening his eyes to painful stimuli and is attempting to remove the mask during resuscitation. He is also producing some inappropriate words. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, heart rate 99 beats/min, and respiratory rate 20 breaths/min. How can his level of consciousness be graded by using the Glasgow coma scale?

answers.option: By using verbal, motor, and eye responses

question: A patient with a spinal cord injury develops a sudden rise in blood pressure. What is the most common cause of autonomic dysreflexia in a patient with a spinal cord injury?

A 25-year-old female presents with a 6-month-long history of drooping of both upper eyelids, transient double-vision, especially in the evening, and fatigue. On examination, she has striking fatigable bilateral ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze with easily visible fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness in neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old shopkeeper, a known case of diabetes, and compliant with his medication, is found obtunded and confused by a customer in his shop. He is taken to a nearby hospital emergency room where he is found to have profuse sweating, and a Glasgow coma scale score of 8/15 (E2, M4, V2). There is no history of fever, fits, or trauma. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths/min, and he has a regular pulse of 99 beats/min. Blood samples are taken for electrolytes, and blood glucose levels. After maintaining airway, breathing, and circulation, what should be the next step in the management of this patient?

A 50-year-old female diagnosed with chronic liver disease for more than eight years is on medical management of the illness. She is found to have an altered sleep pattern with insomnia for the last few days and is started on some sedatives and hypnotics. After taking the first few doses, she became progressively drowsy and is able to move her body and limbs in response to voice stimulation but is not making any eye contact What is her score according to the Richmond agitation sedation score (RASS)?
Which of the following is the most common ophthalmologic feature of multiple sclerosis?
Which of the following conditions occurs as a result of brainstem infarction?

A 30-year-old male, who is a known case of diabetes, was found unconscious by a pedestrian who witnessed stiffness and jerking of the body as well as frothing at the mouth. He is brought to the emergency room where his blood pressure and glucose levels are found to be normal. There is no evidence of any head injury. What is the most appropriate next investigation in this case?
Which of the following statements is the most appropriate regarding subdural hematomas?

answers.option: It can be diagnosed on X-ray skull
It should be drained immediately, regardless of the size of the hematoma
It causes seizures in most cases
It is caused by the rupture of the middle meningeal artery

question: Which of the following central nervous system pathways, when disrupted, result in a coma?

answers.option: Both cerebral hemispheres diffusely, or brainstem ascending reticular activating system

question: Which of the following is an inappropriate investigation to diagnose the cause of coma?
Which of the following statements regarding transient ischemic attacks is true?

answers.option: It is one of the causes of infarction

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate statement about the management of coma?

answers.option: Metabolic causes of coma carry a worse prognosis
Management of the underlying cause is necessary
The patient is nursed in supine position
The patient should be managed in the ICU

question: A 78-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of diminished facial expression (often termed masked facies), stooped posture, slowing of voluntary movement, festinating gait (progressively shortened, accelerated steps), rigidity, and a "pill-rolling" tremor. According to epidemiologic evidence, exposure to which of the following is protective for Parkinson disease (PD)?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, clouding of consciousness, and neck stiffness. A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent cerebrospinal fluid, under increased pressure, with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, an increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content. Bacteria are visible on a smear. Which organism is responsible for causing acute pyogenic (bacterial) meningitis in adolescents and in young adults?
Which of the following is a commonly overlooked initial non-motor symptom of Parkinson disease?
Which of the following options include all four cardinal symptoms that are present in Parkinson disease?

answers.option: Tremor, bradycardia, rigidity, and postural instability
Tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability

question: A 66-year-old male complains of progressive problems with gait, speech, and hand tremors for two years. He also has occasional lightheadedness with standing and a 6-year history of impotence. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. His blood pressure is 140/84 mm Hg lying down, and 98/72 mm Hg standing, without change in pulse. Mental status is normal. He has reduced facial expression, high-pitched dysarthria, and mild anterocollis. There is no resting tremor. He has an irregular tremulousness of both hands when outstretched, worse on the right, without ataxia on finger-to-nose testing. He is bradykinetic and his gait is slow, shuffling, and unsteady. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old HIV-positive male has received no antiretroviral therapy. CT scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage, but there is a midline shift. MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm circumscribed and solid mass. Cytologic examination shows large cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that mark with CD20, but not with GFAP or cytokeratin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Compared to sporadic Parkinson disease (PD), PD that is due to a dominantly inherited mutation in the a-synuclein gene is characterized by which of the following?

answers.option: The stronger association with neuromuscular junction dysfunction
More robust response to dopaminergic therapy
Older age at the onset of symptoms

question: Which of the following is the most common brain tumor in children occurring in the posterior cranial fossa?

A 69-year-old woman has exhibited fluctuating cognitive function, lapses in attention, excessive daytime sleepiness, and periods of disorganized speech over the past 3 years. In the past month, she has had visual hallucinations and memory loss. MR imaging of her brain shows minimal cortical and hippocampal atrophy. A SPECT dopamine transporter scan is abnormal. Which of the following movement problems is she most likely to manifest?

A 50-year-old male, a diagnosed case of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), dies due to meningoencephalitis. A brain autopsy shows soap-bubble lesions, and microorganisms are visible with India-ink preparation. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition?

A 5-year-old boy presents with weakness of both lower limbs. He has no history of trauma. There is a history of upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks back. On examination, power is reduced in both lower limbs, tendon reflexes are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with right-sided weakness within 2 hours after the onset of symptoms. He undergoes a plain CT scan which was unremarkable. Which will be the advantage of diffusion-weighted MRI in this patient?

answers.option: Differentiation between ischemic and hemorrhagic infarct

question: A 39-year-old male is referred for a contrast MRI cervical spine due to weakness and neck pain radiating to the right arm for 18 months. MRI shows an expansion of the cord with a well-defined enhancing intramedullary lesion at C2-C4 level, associated with surrounding edema. The given description best corresponds to which one of the following conditions?

A 40-year-old female presents with right-sided unilateral headaches for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no remarkable findings. The representative gross appearance of the lesion seen on the CT scan of the head shows a dura-based mass. Surgical removal and microscopic examination show elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm with occasional psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman, with history of carcinoma of the right breast, was brought to the clinic with altered mentation for 2 weeks. Her CT scan brain revealed multiple enhancing lesions in brain parenchyma at the grey-white matter junction with perilesional edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old girl stated to her doctor that, "I was walking with my dog in the park suddenly, I started sweating. Since it isn't hot outside, I couldn't quite understand why...then I started having trouble breathing and really got scared. My heart was pounding so hard I thought it might explode out of my chest. My knees felt weak - it seemed like my whole body was shaking, then my arms went numb. Apparently the whole thing only lasted a few minutes, but it felt like each second was an hour. Did I have a heart attack? Am I going crazy? I felt like I was going to die." What is the most likely diagnosis in that girl?

A 6-week-old baby boy is referred to the neurosurgery clinic by a pediatrician as she was concerned about the child's head circumference, which was raised on two successive measurements. The child was born by normal vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was uneventful; the mother has two older children with no medical problems. Both the 12- and 20-week ultrasound scans were normal. Since birth, the baby has been feeding well and not crying unduly. He has not had other symptoms such as fevers or unusual patterns of vomiting. What is the first step in the management of this condition?

A 30-year-old male, when leaving his house in the morning, always has to check the door multiple times to make sure that he has locked his front door. If he tries to leave his house without checking his door, or after only checking it once, he is filled with such anxiety and dread that he must abandon whatever else he is doing to return home and check his front door again. What is the most likely phenomenon this man is struggling with?

Parents of a 10-year-old boy are concerned that their child might be suffering from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Therefore, they brought him to a psychologist for a detailed assessment. Which behavior is most likely consistent with his diagnosis?

answers.option: The child engages in self destructive behavior
The child has been hoarding objects
The child lacks empathy for others

question: A 17-year-old male is brought by his parents to a psychiatric clinic with 3 months history of isolation, poor self-care, self-talking, and refusing to go out. He has a past history of using cannabis. What is the most likely diagnosis of this boy?

A 50-year-old female is brought by her daughter to a psychiatric clinic with complaints of headache, poor sleep, reduced energy, and lack of interest in her life along with suicidal thoughts for the last few months. What is the most likely important feature in her history to make a probable diagnosis?

answers.option: History of similar illness in family

question: A 14-year-old girl who took an overdose of paracetamol in the context of being called fat at school is brought to the emergency department. What is the most important assessment in this case?
A 20-year-old male after a road traffic accident developed alexia but his ability to write was intact. Damage to which of the following structures are likely to present with alexia without agraphia?

answers.option: Right geniculocalcarine tract and corpus callosum
Right geniculocalcarine tract and wernicke's area
Left geniculocalcarine tract and corpus callosum
Left geniculocalcarine tract and wernicke's area
Left geniculocalcarine tract, corpus callosum, and wernicke's area

question: A 3-month-old child presents with an abnormal head shape since birth. He was born at term via normal vaginal delivery. The father has a similar but more accentuated head shape. The physical examination is otherwise normal. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows thickening and ridging at the site of the sagittal suture. When does the growth of the cranial vault cease to occur at the site of sutures?

A 36-year-old male presents with neck and left arm pain. He reports paresthesias in the left index and long fingers. He is found to have weakness of the left triceps muscle and a diminished left triceps jerk. At which vertebral level is his disc herniation most likely to be?

A 55-year-old male presents with lower back pain radiating to both lower limbs. On examination, weakness and decreased reflexes are noted in both limbs. He is suspected for spinal cord compression. Which of the following radiological investigations is the imaging modalities of choice to assess the exact site of abnormality?
Which of the following is not a cause of coma?

A 60-year-old male smoker presents with a complaint of difficulty in walking. He is suspected of a case of vascular disease. Which clinical symptoms support this diagnosis against neurological disease?

answers.option: Poorly localized, bursting pain which relief by bending forward
Electric shock like pain involving whole leg and relieved by bending forward
Poorly localized, electric shock like pain and often in both legs
Poorly localized electric shock like pain in whole leg which relieved by leg elevation
Bursting type of pain involving the whole leg, and relieved by sitting with elevation of leg

question: Which of the following is the most common cause of coma and confusion?
Following a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis on the basis of history and clinical examination, which of the following investigations is the best to confirm the diagnosis?

answers.option: MRI brain and cervical spine with contrast

question: A 9-year-old male is having learning difficulties at school. He has brief lapses of awareness with eyelid fluttering that occurs every 5 to 10 minutes. Which drug would be effective in this child without the additional disadvantages of excessive sedation or tolerance development?

A 5-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fits. Past history reveals attacks of generalized tonic-clonic jerks along with atonic attacks. He has a low IQ and delayed milestones. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old housewife presents to the neurology clinic for evaluation of persistent headache and vomiting for one week with intermittent clouding of consciousness and confusion. She had a prior history of fever and weight loss for more than 2 months. Two years back she was treated for pulmonary tuberculosis and became symptom-free. On examination signs of meningeal irritation were positive with bilateral papilledema. MRI brain contrast study is suggestive of CNS tuberculosis. The cerebrospinal fluid detailed report is awaited. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

A 5-year-old male presents to the clinic with delayed milestones and fits. History reveals the fits to be generalized tonic-clonic jerks with atonic attacks associated with low IQ. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
Which of the following is not a risk factor for stroke?
According to epidemiologic evidence, exposure to which of the following is protective for Parkinson disease (PD)?
Which type of prevention is exemplified by wearing a helmet?
A government decides to educate the common population to spread awareness about a certain disease, so that people are aware of its preventive measures. What type of prevention is this?
A young female presents to the emergency department following a head injury. What is the most appropriate initial investigation in this case?
Control of diabetes and hyperlipidemia is recommended to prevent potential strokes. What type of prevention is this?
Which of the following is considered a subset of a population?

A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of low energy levels throughout the day. Further questioning reveals that she also has a persistent low mood and a lack of interest in things she used to enjoy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following organisms most commonly causes Guillain-Barre syndrome?
Anticonvulsive therapy is provided to patients in order to manage epilepsy patients and keep them seizure-free. What type of prevention is this?
Why is levodopa used instead of dopamine in patients with Parkinson's disease?

A young male is currently taking prescribed amitryptiline for depression. He recently got diagnosed with schizophrenia and is prescribed chlorpromazine for this condition. What is the most major risk of using these two drugs simultaneously?
Which of the following antipsychotic medications is least associated with sedation?
How soon after a stroke should rehabilitation be initiated?
A 7-month-old male presents to the clinic with a history of progressively enlarging head size since birth. What is the initial investigation of choice?
Which of the following is the most common suture involved in craniosynostosis?

answers.option: All involved at the same time

question: An 11-year-old girl presents to the clinic with slowly progressive difficulty maintaining balance. Her symptoms started when she started walking and now have progressed to the extent that she is wheelchair-bound. She has a significant history of recurrent infections. She also has reddish lesions on her ear lobes and conjunctiva. Neurological examination reveals truncal and appendicular ataxia. Other sensations, reflexes, and plantars are normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following are the most severe forms of neural tube defects?
Which of the following is a term used to describe absence seizures?

A 17-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of rigidity in the limbs for one week. He is a known case of schizophrenia and is currently using haloperidol injections for the treatment of psychosis. What is the most appropriate step to manage this patient?
Which of the disease-modifying medications used for multiple sclerosis (MS) is administered via the intramuscular route?

A 70-year-old male patient with a confirmed diagnosis of Parkinson disease presents to the clinic and expresses concern that his medication now takes approximately one hour before it starts to alleviate his symptoms. The patient is currently taking levodopa. What is the term that describes the phenomenon being experienced by this patient?

A 45-year-old male presents with bilateral lower limb weakness which seems to be progressing upwards. A provisional diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome is made. Which of the following features least supports the provisional diagnosis?

answers.option: Normal nerve conduction velocity in the sural nerve
Normal nerve conduction velocities in the first week

question: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with quadriparesis, abdominal pain, and psychiatric symptoms for one day. All of her reflexes are absent apart from the ankle jerk, which is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of central axial block?
